intro: Juncus luteocarpus, commonly known as the yellow-carpus rush, is a flowering plant species native to wetland environments in North America. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that are typically greenish-yellow in color. The plant thrives in moist to wet soils, often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds and lakes. Its rhizomatous growth habit allows it to spread and form dense mats, which can help stabilize soil and provide habitat for various wildlife species. Juncus luteocarpus plays an important ecological role in wetland ecosystems by contributing to nutrient cycling and water filtration.
